Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2017 09:19AM CGG wrote: I can see that would be nerve-wracking. Have you tried to change your view of all the testing? I've always regarded my yearly mammograms as a treat and a positive thing because I greatly appreciate knowing what is going on inside my breasts. So regardless of the good or bad news coming from the tests, I like knowing. So it's a really positive experience for me, regardless of results and stress. As for the testing, it seems that perhaps your mother is scared that that is why she has not filled out the paperwork or done the testing. I encourage you to tell her how important it is to you that she get tested because you are worried about her and because of how the test results impact your life, your breast surveillance, and your desire to get tested yourself. Put in those clear terms, it is almost like a geometry proof that clearly shows that she needs to get tested because of how it impacts you. Perhaps that would help. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2018 10:21PM CGG wrote: I had a similar experience with bruising post lumpectomy, that's normal and to be expected. I developed a large lump/hematoma in the surgery area which bothered me more but I felt better once my doctor told me that it was totally normal for that to develop. The bruise and the lump all went away in good time. If you get a lump/hematoma, massage it everyday and it will go away in a few weeks. Good luck!
